title: Investment Property Becomes Main Residence Then Sold

scenario_info.name: Investment Property Becomes Main Residence Then Sold
scenario_info.description: Amanda purchases an investment property and rents it out for 3 years. She then moves in and lives there as her main residence for 2 years before selling. The six-year absence rule does NOT apply because the property was an investment first. Only the period as main residence qualifies for exemption.

expected_result.notes: After 50% discount. Only lived-in period is exempt. Six-year rule does NOT apply.

applicable_rules: ITAA97 s118.185: Partial main residence exemption
Six-year rule NOT applicable: Property was investment first, then main residence
Only actual residence period (39.98%) is exempt
Key distinction: If MR first then rental, six-year rule would apply

property_history.description: Immediately rented as investment property from day one
Amanda moves in as main residence

properties.notes: Partial exemption (39.98%). Investment first, then main residence = six-year rule does NOT apply. Only the 2-year residence period is exempt. Rental period (3 years / 60.02%) is taxable. Capital gain: $101,550. Taxable after discount: $30,475.

user_query: I bought an investment property and rented it for 3 years. Then I moved in and lived there for 2 years as my main residence. Now I'm selling. Can I use the six-year rule?
